raw_text:
Lib Dems unveil election slogan
 
 The Liberal Democrats will present themselves as "the real alternative" in the forthcoming general election campaign, Charles Kennedy has said.
 
 Unveiling the slogan at the party's spring conference, he said there was no "glass ceiling" to its ambitions. He told delegates that Labour had abused the public's trust and that the Tories had failed to oppose them. In response, the Conservatives insisted that theirs was the party that understood the "forgotten majority".
 
 Speaking in Harrogate Mr Kennedy said: "People want a credible, principled political party which offers a different vision of what Britain can be."
 
 Only the Liberal Democrats stood against the Iraq war, he said, and they had also provided strong opposition to the government's plans on ID cards, anti-terror measures and taxation. He said: "If you voted Conservative in 2001 ... what good did it do you? Your vote was wasted. "What people needed was ... a party which was listening to their concerns; a party which was prepared to stand up and say so; a party which said no to the prime minister." Responding to the claims Tory Party co-chairman Liam Fox said: "Like Labour, the Lib Dems are soft on crime, support higher taxes, oppose controlled immigration and support giving Europe more control over our lives."
 
 Mr Kennedy also outlined his party's plan to impose a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000 a year. The money would be used to help pay for key policies such as abolishing university tuition fees, scrapping council tax in favour of local income tax, and providing free care for the elderly, he said. Labour and the Tories claim the sums do not add up, and that working families would be hardest hit. Mr Kennedy said: "Britain is the fourth-largest economy in the world. We have world class businesses and a world class workforce.
 
 "So why are two million of our pensioners living below the poverty line?" All the parties are campaigning hard for an expected election in May, although Prime Minister Tony Blair has not confirmed any timing. Earlier, Mr Kennedy told Radio 4's Today programme there was no possibility of forming a coalition with Labour in the event of a hung Parliament. "We go into the election as an independent party and we come out as an independent party," he said. Mr Kennedy has been under fire in recent days for missing Monday's Commons vote on the government's controversial anti-terrorism laws, along with 16 other Lib Dem MPs. On Saturday, the Lib Dem chief executive said it was "just a cock-up" that Mr Kennedy and his colleagues missed the vote, which the government won by a majority of only 14. "Nobody had any idea that was going to happen," Lord Rennard told reporters at the party conference. He said he was certain MPs would get another chance to vote against the plans.
llama3.2:1b: The Liberal Democrats will campaign as "the real alternative" in the upcoming general election, with Charles Kennedy saying there is no "glass ceiling" to their ambitions.
They have vowed to stand up for working families and oppose policies that benefit the wealthy, including a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000.
The party has also promised to abolish university tuition fees and provide free care for the elderly.
llama3.2:3b: Liberal Democrats announce their election slogan as "the real alternative" and claim they are the only party opposing Labour's abuse of public trust and the Tories' failure to oppose them.
They propose a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000, funded by abolishing university tuition fees and scrapping council tax in favour of local income tax.
gemma2:2b: The Liberal Democrats are positioning themselves as "the real alternative" in the upcoming election.
They claim they offer a distinct vision of Britain and oppose Labour's actions, while arguing that Tories have failed to stand up against them.
The party unveils a slogan: "real alternative".
They emphasize their opposition to the Iraq war, ID cards, anti-terror measures, and tax increases, highlighting their consistent principled stance.
The Liberal Democrats propose imposing a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000 and allocate funds towards key policies like abolishing tuition fees and scrapping council tax.
Labour and the Tories have criticized the plan's financial feasibility and potential impact on working families.
Mr Kennedy has stated his party is independent of any coalition with Labour in case of a hung parliament.
The Liberal Democrats recently faced criticism for missing a vote on anti-terrorism laws, although the leader insists there will be another opportunity to vote against them.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Lib Dem lawmakers unveil slogan for upcoming election as they oppose Iraq war, tax measures and ID cards.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Liberal Democrats present alternative political vision; criticized by Tories for opposing Iraq war, ID cards and anti-terrorism measures.
Liberal Democrats plan 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100, 000 to help key policies but Labour claims it does not add up for working families.
Lib Dems campaign hard in upcoming election while under pressure from missing Monday's Commons vote on government controversial laws.
qwen2.5:3b: The Liberal Democrats will campaign as the "real alternative" in the upcoming general election, emphasizing their opposition to Iraq war and government policies like ID cards and anti-terror measures.
Charles Kennedy claimed Labour abused public trust and Conservatives failed to oppose them.
He suggested that only the Lib Dems provided strong opposition to these issues and argued they should be a credible party offering a different vision for Britain.
The party plans to impose a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000 annually, with the funds used for policies like abolishing university tuition fees and providing free elder care.
Kennedy dismissed claims from Tory Party co-chairman Liam Fox that Lib Dems are soft on crime, support higher taxes, oppose controlled immigration, or favor increased European Union control.
He also stated that 2 million pensioners in Britain live below poverty line despite the country's economic strength.
The Lib Dem leader ruled out forming a coalition with Labour and insisted they would remain an independent party after the election.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Lib Dems Launch Slogan for election campaign  
Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrats leader, announced a new slogan during the party's spring conference.
He noted no "glass ceiling" to his ambitions, stating Labour had abused public trust and Conservatives failed to oppose them.
The Lib Dems opposed Labour's policies and supported Conservative views on crime, taxes, immigration, and elderly care, despite claiming tax sums weren't enough for working families.
Kennedy outlined a 50% income tax rate for earnings over £100k, aimed at funding education, council taxes, and free elderly care.
He also criticized the Conservative Party's stance on crime and taxes but highlighted their potential coalition issue if Labour wins, with Lib Dems fearing a hung Parliament.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Lib Dem leadership unveiled its election campaigning slogan, "A real alternative for Britain", in response to claims that their opponents were wasting votes by focusing on policies they had previously criticised.

The party leader, Charles Kennedy, said the "real" alternatives to Labour and the Tories would be a more principled, credible political party that stood up against their Iraq war decision and supported different policy areas such as ID cards, anti-terrorism measures, taxation, and care for the elderly.

The party's plan was to impose a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000 and invest in key policies such as abolishing university tuition fees, reducing council tax to local income tax, and providing free care for the elderly.

The coalition of parties is set to take place in May, with the Liberal Democrats expected to campaign for an independent party but not forming a coalition with Labour in the event of a hung Parliament.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Liberal Democrats have unveiled a new election slogan, highlighting their main opposition against the Conservatives and Labour: "The real alternative."
This announcement comes as the party's spring conference is taking place in Harrogate, where they are discussing various topics such as their policy positions on taxation and immigration.
The slogan highlights that despite being labelled as a "party of hope," the Lib Dems believe their ideas can help Britain move forward and improve people's lives.

In addition to this new election slogan, Charles Kennedy has also addressed delegates by insisting that Labour, the Conservatives, and the Tories all have a responsibility to listen to their concerns and change for the betterment of everyone.
phi:2.7b: The Liberal Democrats will use "the real alternative" slogan in their general election campaign, as they are the only party that opposed the Iraq war and have strong opposition to Labour's policies on issues such as taxation and immigration.

They plan to impose a 50% income tax rate for earnings over £100,000 per year and use the revenue to fund key policies such as abolishing university tuition fees and providing free care for the elderly.
The Conservatives claim that this is not financially viable and could hurt working families.
Labour also opposes some of these proposals but has not offered an alternative.
Mr Kennedy stated that he will not form a coalition with Labour if there is a hung Parliament.
He missed a recent Commons vote on anti-terrorism laws, which the government passed by a narrow margin, and claimed it was just a "cock-up".
The Lib Dem chief executive said they would have another chance to vote against the plans.
orca-mini:3b: The Liberal Democrats will present themselves as "the real alternative" in the forthcoming general election campaign, according to Charles Kennedy.
The party has ambitions that are not limited by a "glass ceiling", he said.

Labour and the Conservatives have abused the public's trust and Tory Party co-chairman Liam Fox opposes key policies such as abolishing university tuition fees, scrapping council tax in favor of local income tax, and providing free care for the elderly.
The Lib Dems plan to impose a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000 a year.
Labour and the Tories claim the sums do not add up and that working families would be hardest hit.
The Liberal Democrats are campaigning independently of the other parties and will come out as an independent party in the election.
hermes3:3b: Lib Dem unveils election slogan "the real alternative", opposing Iraq war and govt policies; aims to impose 50% income tax on earnings over £100,000.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Liberal Democrats unveiled their election slogan, "the real alternative," during their spring conference, with Charles Kennedy stating there was no limit to their ambitions.
The party stood against the Iraq war and provided strong opposition to government plans on ID cards, anti-terror measures, and taxation.
Kennedy outlined their plan to impose a 50% income tax rate on earnings over £100,000 a year, explaining that Britain has enough wealth to address poverty among pensioners.
Despite Prime Minister Tony Blair not confirming an expected election in May, Kennedy emphasized the party's independence ahead of any potential coalition with Labour in a hung Parliament.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Liberal Democrats, led by Charles Kennedy, launched their election campaign with the slogan "the real alternative," positioning themselves as a credible and principled choice against Labour and the Conservatives.
Kennedy criticized Labour for betraying public trust and the Tories for failing to oppose them.
He highlighted the Lib Dems' opposition to the Iraq war, ID cards, anti-terror laws, and taxation policies.
The party proposed a 50% tax on earnings over £100,000 to fund policies like scrapping university tuition fees, replacing council tax with local income tax, and providing free elderly care.
Labour and the Tories dismissed the financial viability of these plans.
Kennedy ruled out a coalition with Labour in a hung Parliament.
He also faced criticism for missing a key anti-terrorism vote, which party officials attributed to a scheduling mistake.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Liberal Democrats will campaign as "the real alternative" in the upcoming general election, with Charles Kennedy stating there is no ceiling for their ambitions.
Labour has been accused of trust abuse, while Conservatives claimed they understand the "forgotten majority."
The party opposed the Iraq war and provided strong opposition to ID cards, anti-terrorism measures, and taxation.
They plan to impose a 10% income tax rate on earnings over £X per year.
Both Labour and Conservatives have criticized their plans.
Kennedy also outlined key policies for his party, including abolishing tuition fees, scrapping council tax, and providing free care for the elderly.
Prime Minister Tony Blair has not confirmed an election timing; however, it's uncertain whether a coalition with Labour is possible in a hung Parliament.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Liberal Democrats have introduced their election slogan, positioning themselves as "the real alternative" in the upcoming general election.

Charles Kennedy, speaking at the party's spring conference in Harrogate, emphasized their commitment to offering a distinct vision for Britain, contrasting with perceived failures of Labour and Conservative policies on issues like Iraq war support, ID cards, anti-terror measures, and taxation.
The Lib Dems claim they were the only party against the Iraq war and have consistently voiced opposition to government plans on these matters.
Kennedy criticized Conservatives for wasting votes when they supported Labour in 2001, arguing that voters needed a party attuned to their concerns and ready to challenge the prime minister.

In response, Tory Party co-chairman Liam Fox accused the Lib Dems of being soft on crime, supporting higher taxes, opposing controlled immigration, and advocating for increased European influence over Britain's affairs.
The Lib Dem plan includes imposing a 50% income tax rate on earnings above £100,000 to fund key policies such as free university tuition, elimination of council tax, and elderly care.

Critics, including Labour and the Conservatives, argue that this would disproportionately impact working families, while the Lib Dems maintain Britain's economic strength should enable better support for pensioners, who currently live below the poverty line despite being part of the fourth-largest economy globally.
Despite campaigning vigorously, Kennedy confirmed that the party wouldn't form a coalition with Labour in case of a hung Parliament; instead, they would remain independent.
Recently, Kennedy faced criticism for missing a vote on anti-terrorism laws due to a technical error, which he described as "just a cock-up."
The Lib Dem chief executive expressed confidence that MPs would have another opportunity to vote against the government's plans.
